values:
Add it if you're interested!

http://noisybenign.livejournal.com

The feeling that I'll never meet an interesting furry has been flooded out by a strong sense of inadequacy now that I know how many cool and interesting furries are actually out there.  This is the La Nina of my discontent.

Well that's not entirely true, but the competition makes me feel like a bit of a bore, especially considering all I've been doing for the last six months is working at a gas company and avoiding the possibility of making new friends in the real world.

So in an epic attempt to get something interesting going I've decided to get some shit off my chest.

I've been trying to write a cathartic autobiography for about a year now.  Maybe once a month I write a first chapter.  I come back and read it, and I hate it.  There doesn't seem to be any way for me to honestly write about my life without sounding like a self-loathing egotistical prig.  The thought disturbs.  Combine it with the fact that I really have little of interest to write about and you really begin to meet the man.

Everything I write for my friends strikes me as more interesting and pointed than what I write down for myself, or what I write down argumentatively.  I don't know what that means, but it doesn't feel like a good thing.  I'm still way too critical of myself.

I'm annoyed by the fact that people don't want to meet me on my terms.  The oblivious roommate found out I was a furry last week when he asked me how my love life was going.  We awkwardly laughed for a little while as we walked to Coles.  I told him if he wanted to know anything about being a furry he could just ask me.  He hasn't asked me any questions yet.  So does he have an accurate image of what being a furry requires?  I doubt it.  He's from the internet.

I'm annoyed by the fact that I have a furry journal.  That thought shits me.  This journal has always been a dumping ground for my furriness and not much else.  I want to create a journal where I can combine both my rants about how shitty the Six Sigma management technique is, and how Anfael makes me lol.  I want to reconcile those parts of my identity.  I resolve that the next post I make here will be a link to my new journal.

I'm annoyed by the fact that conglomerating my identity into one blog feels like some kind of positive movement when really it just boils down to a meaningless gesture.

I'm annoyed by the fact that I started the last three paragraphs with the same phrase.

I'm annoyed.

i asked an internet-famous furry to draw me randomly because he was just hanging around so i was like "what up" actually what i really said was draw a raptor on a scooter riding down the internet superhighway lol

Basically I've discovered I'm just another shitty furry rights activist.

The problem is that whenever I hear someone reasonable and open minded make an incorrect statement about furries I feel like a part of my labeled identity has been annexed by the jerks that came before me and didn't have the courage to correct them.

But the thing is that there probably weren't any jerks that came before me.  I'm the only jerk around.  I'm one of the ones that goes outside, that actually hangs out with a wide variety of non-furs.  If I don't correct people and tell them its not all about fursuits and bestiality, who will?

I don't think it is easy to enter into this world.  There really isn't a place to go that is exclusively for people that are curious or uncertain about this whole boondoggle.  You're either in or you are out.

There isn't any visible moderate presence here either, especially for someone new.  The people you see and hear the opinions of are the ones that are on extreme edges.  The drama is what gets the attention.  Flaming faggots and whiny crybabies stick out like a sore thumb.

So I aim to create a place for clarity.  I want to be part of a repository of thought free from sensationalism.  I want to make one.

I think furry has more appeal than the currently limited fanbase suggests.  I want it to become BDSM-like in scope.  This is 100% selfish, since I would get to feel less alienated.

Fluffy handcuffs are an example of light bondage.  Why can't bunny ears on a girl be light furry?

Argh.

What am I thinking.

[23:51] raptorbator> I just debated for an hour with a #dragonyiff op who thought fever wasn't a defense mechanism and was just a symptom, and he still didn't fucking believe me.
[23:51] raptorbator> what a waste of goddamn time
[23:51] raptorbator> well, guess I'll just have to shove another furry into my big ol' box of stereotypes
[23:51] raptorbator> sure is getting FUCKING CROWDED IN THERE

Thank you lord for this, our daily yiff.  Thank you for dragon cocks, livejournal and scaly chicks.  Thank you for the slutty lions, foxes, horses and wolves.  Thank you for creating tails, barbs, ridges, fur and knots for use in our many works, a divine gift to us all.  You have truly blessed us with imageboards, IRC and the furries that are so perverted, plentiful, and technically proficient.  Thank you for those magnificently shining paragons of our community, the artists that waste their talent on our niche porn.  Thank you for the internet, which made this all possible.  Amen.

That furmeet made all my fears kind of slide away.

I talked to some pretty sociable people that obviously had their heads on straight.  I have a feeling I didn't meet the most undesirable elements of the brisbane furries, because me and my friend mostly stood in the corner of the patio, hands in pockets.  Anyone who was judgemental or interested in hierarchy must have immediately dismissed us.  Anyone who had no social skills wouldn't have talked to us.

Flamedrake, Dash, Zwabbe, FoxyMalone, Broc and kchikitty(?) thanks for making us feel welcome.  I really stayed in my comfort zone and almost tackled Dash, who I already knew a little, and proceeded to talk to him a lot, but hey, I personally was nervous as hell.  

It was such a flood of newness, and both me and my best friend weren't too comfortable.  He later said he felt like he would have felt if he was around a bunch of guys wearing light BDSM gear.  I totally understand, and personally I was ready to leave when he was.  It was just such an intense, totally overhyped (in my own head) experience for me, the apex of my furry experience.  I believe, and hope, that it will be fairly familiar and unintimidating from here on in.

But really, phew.  I was expecting it would be a lot worse and desperately hoping it wouldn't be.

I'm gonna show up to more shindigs, for sure.

Thanks so much to my best friend, who along with my other friends has been such a great support through this strange time in my life.

Time to let it slide.

[From a post on a oekaki image board]

I believe my true self is that of a 1978 Honda Civic. That is who I truly am on the inside, my soul-being. To express this aspect of my personality I draw pictures of myself as an anthropomorphic 1978 Honda Civic and share them with others of my kind. My girlfriend is an 1975 AMC Gremlin, and we are soul-mates. Automobile soul-mates. I communicate with others of my kind mostly through the internet, but sometimes we attend conventions. People persecute us for our true selves. My neighbor threatened to call the cops on me just for talking to his Escort. I'm not even into Fords, but that's besides the point. Just because I AM a car doesn't mean I'm going to have relations with just every car I see. It's not about the sex, though there is a 1955 Chevy Bel-Air I will never forget. You never forget your first. But I'm sick of people saying I'm perverted and wrong, and that I'm not really a car I'm just crazy. They don't understand, I have just as much right to the road as they do. Those assholes at the DMV are the worst, but I'd rather not talk about that ugly incident of carsecution. I have a good mechanic, though. You've never lived until you've had this guy change your oil. It doesn't make me gay, because I'm a Honda, not really a person. Your morality doesn't apply to me. I am a car. Beep beep, mother fucker. Deal with it.

---

I'm perfectly accepting of cars, but you have to realize that the vast majority of people aren't. It's not like the drive around in their tires every day, they just can't empathize. I had a good friend that was a 1968 Black Cadillac, and even though people always looked at us funny, I enjoyed being around him. He was one of the most insightful auto-motive beings I've ever met.

I hope society can one day be more accepting and compassionate towards Cars, but until then, maybe keep it under wraps?

---

The day I realized I was a automorph was when I watched the Pixar film, Cars. The way Lightning revved his engines made my cock harder than ever before. I thought it was strange at first, then I grew to accept my car loving ways. I soon realized that deep down inside, I was a 1974 Ford Pinto. I kept this to myself until a few years ago when I found out there was a convention for people like me! It was called Three-on-the-Tree International and I met some amazing autophiles like me. I met this really cute guy who had made a Ford Mustang costume out of a cardboard box. It was love at first sight and we're now garage mates.

Fuck the oppressors! I'm a Pinto, goddamnit!

---

It really pisses me off that everyone is some high and mighty expensive sportscar or some rugged and powerful SUV.

Sure, it's your fantasy and you can be whatever you want, but those cookie-cutter carsonas are going on my nerves.

NOONE is a Toyota Corolla, EVER and IRL it's one of the most common cars on the planet!

And you totally can't roleplay with those SUV idiots and their power trips, expecially the Hummer guys.
Do they have to compensate for something IRL? Always crushing this and running over that. Pfff.

And red Sportscars? Totally pipe-sluts, they're all the same and SO unoriginal.
After Cars EVERYONE made a red sportscar car-acter.

---

I'm so confused!
I'm horny for Catbus!
Am I car or cat fixated?
Eyes of supple lavender are the first greetings any eyes would meet themselves to.

Ok this Naten dude talked to me again.

Don't click any of the links in this chatlog unless you like looking at orange dino penis.

Before this point it was pretty much just small talk.  Then I asked him how he found out about furries.

Like hell he didn't want a link!

If this isn't some kind of crazy hoax or extended foreplay, I'm pretty happy this guy has someone to talk to.  There is so much argument about the base definition of a furry from within the community that people just can't talk about it without getting yelled at by someone.  I wish I had someone I could comfortably chat with when I was dabbling.  Instead all I encountered was aloof insular narcissists with no interest in talking to new people, or even welcoming them.
</lj-cut>

I find it impossible to enjoy being a dom. :(

For me the word furry doesn't extend beyond being a definition of my sexual proclivities.

I think there are people that are in this fandom just because they want to be.

I am not one of them.

I don't want to be a furry, but its a bit late to change that now.  My psych told me I could stop it, but I don't want to have to train myself to be normal by treating what seems natural to me as dangerous.  Seems a bit too degrading.

I am a furry, but its not because I want to be special or attract attention.  If I wanted to attract attention I would wear ears and a tail everywhere in public and yell about fursecution.

Seems like a fair few people think that it is just a choice.

I had an important discussion with one of my e-pals last night. He had just found out I was a furry faggot, and he was pretty concerned. The reason he was concerned was that he has seen people use these personal traits as crutches, to base their whole identities around. Those of you who know me really well will probably be laffoing at this point, but I haven't been the most social guy in the last little while, so I can see how you would make this mistake. Let me be perfectly honest and straightforward about this... There is nothing I find more hilarious than people that build their personalities up around one particular label or character trait. When I act like a total nerd and wear a LOL INTERNET T-shirt, I am actively satirizing people that build their personalities up around the nerd label. I mean, I fucking love nerdy shit. It's hilarious how well I fit the mould. It's hilarious. But there is no way that I will refuse to participate in something because it isn't nerdy enough. There is no way that I will spurn a person because they don't hold the same interests as me. A fair few people just think I'm a nerd, but most of them are people that would irrationally reject everything nerdy due to their own strong identification with a subculture. If someone thinks they are too good for nerds they probably won't talk to me, which I think has contributed to culling a lot of intolerant people from my friendship group. Don't get me wrong, as a general rule I love nerd shit, but I actually like it, I'm not participating just because every other nerd is. I apply the above to furry shit as well. If you ever see me wearing a button up silk shirt with a wolf howling at the moon on it, you know whats up. >8)
